This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 My name is Patrick Bares. I'm located in Munich, Germany. I'm working for the Senior Threat
Research Team for Splunk. My colleagues are mainly, yeah, are mainly located in the US.
In my free, in my time, I really like to contribute to open source projects. Like you see a bunch
of them here. There's a tech range, security content, Sigma to Splunk Alert, Sigma hunting
app. During this difficult time, COVID, I start to play games a little bit again. That's
why I'm a hobby StarCraft 2 player in the moment. If you like to play, let me know.
During the same time, we can talk about detections and so on. And you can follow me in Twitter
under at Bares underscore Patrick. I want to start a little bit with an introduction
because I don't know the skill set of all the people attending today. That's why we
just want to start. What is the detection? What are the challenges and why we need continuous
delivery? First of all, have a look into a simple attack. We probably all heard about
this attack back to credential dumping. Have a look in the short agenda. And sorry, that's
now another version, but we'll make it work. I will first talk about what is continuous
integration? What is continuous development? Then what are the challenges? And then we
take a look into the different stages like version control, continuous integration,
continuous delivery, and continuous deployment. Let's have a look into continuous integration,
continuous delivery, and continuous deployment. All this wording comes mainly from software
development. Software development had a similar challenge as we have it in the detection
development that they often had bugs in the code after release very often as we have to
release new detections. And that's why they build it on top of some kind of four pillars.
The first one was the version control. They had software like GitHub and GitLab to control the
code and see the changes in the code and running some actions when there is new code.
Then there was continuous integration. Continuous integration focusing on compiling, validating,
doing code review, doing unit testing. For example, when I built a bunch of new piece of code,
like a new feature, I will also develop some unit tests for it. And then I can test that specific
part of the code. And then there's also integration testing. Integration testing in this case is then
testing the complete software as a whole, which means not only the whole feature,
like the complete app. Then we have continuous delivery. Continuous delivery is when we have now
developed a new version of the code, we want to get them very fast into production. We don't
have to want to wait another three months until it is available for the whole customer base.
That's why there is automation in place, which will directly put them into continuous testing,
test if everything works, perform user acceptance tests, and so on. And last but not least,
continuous deployment, which means it will be deployed into the production.
And when we take a look in a very modern applications, they deploy a new version
couple of days. You probably will not notice it, but in the background, it will have a new
Facebook version and that multiple times a day. And when we have a look into a CICD,
there is the code. It always starts with the code. Then you do some commits and some work
on the code. Every new version of the code is a commit. And it's then divided into multiple
branches. We'll see it later. And then there is the CI pipeline, which focus on building code,
running unit tests, and running the integration tests.
This is everything for testing and for development. And then the CD pipeline,
the continuous delivery or continuous deployment pipeline, is then putting that into a complete
staging environment to test it as a whole app. And of course, also pushing it to production.
What are the challenge for us when we know how CICD works,
especially in software development? What are the challenge for us as detection developer?
First of all, what I see is like this threat landscape is changing very fast.
Like if you then develop detection once a year, and then you say, like, I developed now
50 detections. And then you work like the whole year. And then in the start of next year,
say you develop another 50 detection. I think this is not how it can work today. I think
the detections need to be continuously improved, continuously deployed, and so on. That's why we
need a very agile way of getting these detections, a very automated way into the product.
A very automated way into the production and change it and adapt it and improve it.
Then also infrastructure. In corporate environments, always new infrastructure comes up.
And that's why false positives can be then come up later, which needs an improvement
in the detections and so on. And what we also want to do is improve the detection development
process. Because when it takes for us too long to develop new detections, then we are just too
slow. Then we already had a tech and we only can see that the tech happened, but we can't
see it directly when it happened and avoid it. Another few challenges is deployment.
I don't know who already deployed some detections to a theme in a manual way.
And that can take quite some time. You have to search itself, the detection itself,
but you also provide a lot of meta information around it, like what should happen when the
detection will trigger, how often it should run, like some kind of cron schedule and so on. There's
also a lot of meta information and manual deployment can take a lot of time.
And then we have testing. I think three, four years ago, we didn't have that much detections
out there. Now we have a lot of cool projects, a lot of companies like Elastic, Splunk, Microsoft,
they're all open source, the detections. But now we need to really focus on that they all
have a high quality, that they are tested all the time, that they're tested with change parameters.
That's why it's very important that we test the detections properly. And then the tuning can be
then done in the security operations center. And then we have version control. Often the
things that are not version controlled, that should be also changed, that they are version
controlled. We see the changes over time and so on. Now let's have a look into the different
pillars. The first one was version control. For version control, you have different software. You
have either GitHub or GitLab, and it works based on... The focus is that many different people
can work on the same project, which means in this case, like concurrent development.
And you see then there's like this, all these different pieces here are the different branches.
Everybody can work in his own branches, make his own changes, develop new detections.
At one point, we make a pull request, which means we merge again to the main branch,
which is sometimes developed for development and the master then for release or productive.
Then what we can also do very good with this version control platforms like GitHub and GitLab,
we can start to trigger some automation. We can start to trigger a continuous integration pipeline
when there is some change or some pull request opened, or when we have some new code in there,
we can test it for bugs and so on. It also helps very good in collaboration.
It also tracks changes and some bad thing happened, there's error in there. You can go back
to a previous state and it should be fixed. And often that platforms are focused on high
availability, disaster recovery. GitHub is like probably you all know it, it's like owned by
Microsoft now, you can there have your own projects. And GitLab is like the same version,
but you can also deploy it in your own environment. I know some security operation centers
have a very strict, have no connections to the internet. If they want to use something
like continuous integration, continuous delivery, then GitLab can be the right choice.
Then we have version control in detection development. In this case, you see the first
branch, which is the master branch. The master branch is normally that what you want to run in
production. At least that's how we do it. Then there is the develop branch. Develop branch is
like the starting point. You start normally from the develop branch, and then different people
create their own branches in order to develop their own detections. For example, here in this
case, when detection engineer one develops a new detection, he will create his own branch
from the develop branch. He's working on his changes. And then when he thinks he's ready,
he will then make a pull request, which then gets refuted by someone else. And that will be
merged back to develop. And then normally you want to put multiple changes, multiple new detections
together into one branch, and then merge it to master back. And then normally some automation
should run and push that to production. Continuous integration.
Continuous integration needs, in detection development, focus on different aspects.
In this case, we have like the oils when we branch, and then we have the merge, which I said
emerges in kind of a pull request. And then what should be done is peer review.
Peer review means that somebody else takes a look over your detection. He needs to package
the detection, needs to validate the detections, needs to refute the detection rule, and perform
some unit testing, integration testing. One moment.
And this, when we don't use automation, that needs to be done everything manually. You have
to do that with every new pull request. That's why this needs to be automated.
What we use for our projects, for security content, for example, this is our open source
projects for detections, is CircleCI. CircleCI is one of the many platforms which you then can use
to run your automation chops. And for package detections and validate detections, we have a
chop, which will then turn, we describe our detections in a YAML format.
Maybe I have an example later. And then turn it into a whole package which can be then used
with Splunk. In this case, it will validate the content. It will validate the content, which means
all the fields are in there, in the structure. Build the sources, which means take this YAML
format and build Splunk configuration files out of it. And then also test if everything was built,
that it's also some further checks based on this Splunk app.
And then we have unit testing and integration testing. Unit testing, integration testing
is done with us, with one of our open source projects, which is Attack Range. And I will
want to give you a little bit more information. In case you missed the link, it's just like you
Google Attack Range GitHub, and you will come to our open source project.
The open source project Attack Range has three main goals. First, it will focus on
building a lab infrastructure, then simulate some attacks with different engines. The best
support we have is Atomic Red Team. And then we can use the generated data to test detections,
because we don't want to test it with some data which is staying out, right? We want to really
see the real attacks and then provide proper detections for the real attacks. That's why we
need to run the real attacks. And that's why I also totally would highlight again what Vitaly
said in the keynote. As a detection developer, as a blue teamer, you also need to know the red
team side. You are able to know what kind of attacks they're using, how they achieve lateral
movement, how they achieve their goals. When you have a look into Atomic Red Team project,
there you see a lot of different possibilities, how they achieve the different goals of
initial compromise or lateral movement or credentialing.
Then we have the Attack Range architecture. The Attack Range builds multiple systems.
It's building a Windows domain controller, a Windows server, and a Windows 10 client.
Everything is already pre-configured. It's also part of a whole domain.
And all the configurations, all the logging is also already configured. You will get
the Sysmon logs. You will get Windows event logs. You will get PowerShell logs.
In this case, use then Splunk as a theme. But there's also, in case you don't use Splunk,
you'll use Elastic or Sentinel. There are a bunch of other projects out there who do
similar things. This is just as an example. And then we have multiple Universal Forwarder
in there, which send then the logs to Splunk. And Splunk using the so-called technical add-ons
to pass the logs that you get your key value pairs. And with the key value pairs,
you can build your detections. Then we also have Caldera deployed if you want to run a
complete attack scenario. As I already said, Atomic Red Team to run specific attacks,
what I like to name it as unit tests for detection development. And in case you want to test some
own exploits, some new exploits or a meta-exploit, you can use Kali Linux.
The attack range, this is a little bit older diagram. Yeah, there was some confusion with
the slides. The attack range itself, there is now an attack range and an attack range local. We
split it up into two diagrams. But in this case, it still shows the one diagram. The attack range
local, which you see on the upper part, can be built with Vagrant and VirtualBox.
And you just run that single command, you wait 20, 25 minutes, and you have a complete lab where
you can start to work. You can start to develop detection, the logs are coming to Splunk,
you can start to attack the environment and so on. And the other way, which is our preferred
way for the future is using Terraform and the AWS Cloud to build the attack range.
The attack range is then leveraging Ansible for configuration management. It's leveraging Ansible
to provision the Windows servers and also to provision the Splunk server. You can either
install multiple servers, you can install all three servers, you can install also in Phantom,
which is like an enterprise security, everything what you need.
Let's have a look into example. And as I said, it's a little bit older slides,
that's where you don't see the already new released sub-techniques of the MITRE ATT&CK
matrix. That's still the older versions with just the techniques. In case you didn't see it,
but probably most of you already saw the ATT&CK matrix. The MITRE ATT&CK matrix is a collection
of tactics, techniques, and procedures which attackers are using to attack the environment.
Which attackers are using to achieve their goals. In the dark gray background,
probably you can't read it, you just can go to the MITRE ATT&CK website and you see it probably
better. With the dark gray background, you see the different adversary technical goals.
For example, adversary in order to be successful needs to have some way of initial access,
completely on the left side. It needs some way of execute things. Then it wants to
gain persistence, privilege escalation, and so credential access. And then as the white boxes,
that are the different possibilities what an attacker can use to achieve that goal.
For example, when we have a look into credential access,
one way of an attacker to get credentials is to use credential dumping.
Credential dumping is a technique to dump the credentials and then afterwards your traffic
as an attacker when you move from one machine to other one. It's not that noisy anymore because
use valid credentials and differentiate. Then you misusing that credentials from a valid
administrator use the credentials is very difficult. That's why it's a very popular
technique of attackers to use the credentials. Credential dumping has them when we have a look
into Atomic Red Team for that specific technique has now 13 different possibilities to do it.
Even now, it's a project which getting more and more contributions. I think now it's even more
tests, which means in this case, we have 13 different tests for Atomic Red Team from using
Mimikatz and PowerShell to create volume shadow copies and so on.
With the Atomic Red Team, you can now simulate all the 13 different attacks.
And then you can use, you start to develop detection that you see all the different variants
and you can start to focus what kind of logs do I need when I start to attack it and which kind of
logs do I see it in PowerShell logs, in Sysmon logs, or do I even see it in the Windows event logs.
And now with the attack range, you can do that kind of unit testings for detection rules,
which means you build an attack range, like you configure it, you have half an hour,
it is running, and then you run the simulate command. And the simulate command you provide
with minus T is the similar, it's for target. You specify on which target you want to run that,
the credential dumping attack, and then it will run all that 13 different attacks on domain controller.
In this case, it was then the domain controller. And then you can use Splunk or you can directly
jump into the Sysmon logs with the Windows event viewer to see what happened now with the
different attacks and what log sources can I leverage and how can I detect now these different attacks.
And then we have continuous delivery.
Continuous delivery is now focusing, we develop now our new detections,
with the attack range or with other projects. And now we need to get that detection into production.
And before we do that, we want to do this kind of user acceptance test,
what I said, like we want to test everything together. Now, how we can do that? We have now,
for example, in this print, we developed 10 new detections. Now we have 20 detections in total.
Now what we can do, we can leverage another open source project, which is also integrated
into a tech range called Aldera. It's also from the MITRE guys. And Caldera is now focusing
complete on attack simulation. And not only on the different smaller texts by itself,
it chains and complete attack together from initial access to some executions, to some persistence,
lateral movement, and so on. You can develop your own complete scenario.
And you can then use the complete scenario to test the complete set of detections. In this case,
we can then test all our 20 detections and we can see at which points we saw that attack.
It's also an open source project. You can also find it in GitHub.
And it's also always changing. They are working heavily on it. And as I said, like Caldera can be
very good used for that complete attack chain when you want to test the whole detections together.
And Atomic Red Team can be very good used if you want to test every detection by itself
with the corresponding attack.
And then, yeah, as I said, you can then specify a whole complete scenario here. In this case,
there is, you can also divide it in different phases. You can also say that it should dump
the history of the command line. It should, yeah, it should have a look into the admin shares if
it finds further credentials and so on. Then we have continuous deployment.
Now what we want to get is we have now all the detections in our version controlled GitHub
or GitHub. And now we want to get them somehow in our scene. And that is still,
we use Splunk here as an example, but that applies to all other different scene vendors.
Often what we see is either they provide some kind of packaging that you provide,
you build a complete package, and then you install that package onto the scene.
Or what is, in my opinion, more like modern approach is when a scene provides some kind
of REST API and you use a REST API to then put the detections into the scene.
As I probably said, one of our projects which we use is Splunk Security Content. It's also
an open source project. You will find there more than 200 detections. If you need to have some new
ideas for new detections, have a look in there. We map everything to the MITRE ATT&CK matrix,
which is also our blueprint in terms of detection development, which means we use the ATT&CK matrix
in order to focus on the most used ATT&CK vectors. Then everything is mapped to the
common information data model, which is something in order to normalize data. You also see the
similar things for other scene vendors, which the idea behind is that when you have
different log sources, for example, from different firewall vendor, that at the end,
in your scene, you still can query it with the same key values, that you don't have a source IP,
which is spelled four times different, that you have one normalization of data,
which you then can query. That's called data normalization.
And we are very open to contribution. If you have some new, cool ideas of detections,
please contribute it to our project. That would be very cool and everybody would benefit of it.
I think we as Blue Teamer, as Defender, we need to work together and share our detections
in order to keep up with the speed of the adversaries.
And how do we do it in the moment? It's like there is our security content project. And then,
as I said, we have this Circus CI tool, which is then running automation when we do a new pull
request or if we merge some new code to develop. It will then do all the steps, which I told you,
I package the detections, do some testing, validate the content, build our own app.
This is for us, everything is automated, which means when we merge something to develop,
it will build for us a complete new Splunk app. And that Splunk app consists then of all the
detections. And in this case, it's a Splunk ES content update. And then you can just install it.
And then what we also have, we have also all our detections
in using our available SRS API. And that's also changing all the time, but you can go
to docs.splunkresearch.com. And then you find all the detections, which you can then query over REST
API. And we try to provide more and more parameters, which means now you should also
be able to query them by MITRE technique. For example, you want to see what the Splunk
security research team can offer us in terms of detections for credential dumping,
then you use a parameter T1003, and then you get all the detections what we have for credential
dumping. It was a little bit faster. Thank you very much.
